reviewText: Love all of Bob's movie...Never dull.
Great old fashion classic western for the whole family where you know who the good guys and bad guys are.

Another reviewer states that both of these films are fully restored and re-mastered. They are not. Fortunately, Alpha came up with some pretty good prints this time around, though perfectionists may still complain about a few scratches, splices and less than pristine quality. I'm very pleased with how good these movies look.

KID COURAGEOUS (1935) has Steele, an all-round athletic college type being thrown onto a boxcar heading west by his all-business father (Lafe McKee). Steele's hog-tied and is set free by fellow boxcar stowaway Kit Gard who befriends Bob in his quest to find his father's missing mine engineer. This makes no sense since Bob earlier pleaded with dad Lafe to let him go west to investigate the disappearance instead of sitting around the office all day conducting business.
Anyway, Bob and Kit get to the bottom of things after the usual mistaken identity stuff and several very good Steele scenes involving an excellent brawl in which runty Bob hurls his opponent around with apparent ease and a swordfight duel in which Bob once again proves his mettle and athletic skill.
This is quite an enjoyable B-Western, easy going and lots of fun with Bob Steele at the peak of his cowboy stardom, the charming smile and twinkle in his eye honed to perfection.
And Bob's real life father, Robert North Bradbury directed this gem.

The second here, NEAR THE RAINBOW'S END (1930) is the real treat of this double feature. It's Bob Steele's first talking picture and it's in really good shape. Once again Lafe McKee is Bob's father, so this can also be considered a father-son double bill!
This time it's the cattle vs sheep stuff with Al Ferguson turning in a really nasty performance as the low-down snake behind murdering Loise Lorraine's kindly father. This one is directed by prolific veteran J.P. McGowan and it moves right along for a very early outdoor sound feature.

So what we have here is a pretty good time on the Western frontier circa 1930s. Two excellent Bob Steele features, slam-bang action-packed! A very good example of this kind of stuff. And they are both in nice shape and very watchable.
It's coming across a real bargain like this that keeps me coming back to the ALPHA product, although sometimes their product leaves a lot to be desired. But, hey, they are the leading source for B-Western entertainment out there with the largest catalog to be offered...and they're CHEAP! So, yeah, you get what you pay for, but sometimes you come up with something really great.

Poverty Row Pictures presents "KID COURAGEOUS/NEAR THE RAINBOW'S END" (1930/1935) (109 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) -- Bob Steele was an American actor --- He was born Robert Adrian Bradbury in 1907 in Portland, Oregon, into a vaudeville family --- Bob's career began to take off for good in 1927, when he was hired by production company Film Booking Offices of America (FBO) to star in a series of Westerns. Bob--who was rechristened Bob Steele at FBO--soon made a name for himself, and in the late 1920s, 1930s and 1940s starred in B-Westerns for almost every minor film studio, including Monogram, Supreme, Tiffany, Syndicate, Republic (including several films of the Three Mesquiteers series) and Producers Releasing Corporation (PRC) (including the initial films of their "Billy the Kid" series)

In the late 1940s and early 1950s, that "new medium" television had many hours to fill and few dollars to fill them --- They re-discovered the B-Western, still a popular mainstay of Saturday afternoon matinees and many cowboy stars thrilled a new audience --- Taking advantage of this rebirth in popularity, publishers brought to the marketplace comic books featuring these western heroes of "Bob Steele" Westerns --- These bimonthly issues were copyrighted in February and April of 1950 by Fawcet Publications --- His career which included nearly 200 feature films, serials and TV appearances --- Steele in his twilight years at the age 59 when he got the part of the cantankerous "Trooper Duffy", in the western comedy series "F Troop" (1965), who at the drop of a hat would give his rendition of fighting "shoulder to shoulder with Davy Crockett at the Alamo" --- Steele retired from the screen in 1973 --- Bob's long career, spanning more than 50 years came to an end in 1988 when he passed away.

The first film of this double feature - "KID COURAGEOUS" (1 February 1935 ) (53 mins/B&W)

Under the production staff of:
Robert North Bradbury  - Director / Screenwriter
A.W. Hackel  - Producer
William Hyer  - Cinematographer
Roy S. Luby  - Editor

Our story line and plot, our hero Bob Steele is once again directed by his true life father Robert North Bradbury --- aboard a train Steele arrives west and is forced to trade places and clothes with Bill Patton the outlaw Apache Joe --- could this be the same outlaw that is holding Barney Furey the missing mining engineer of the Bannister mine --- is Jack Cowell taking gold from the mine and planning to kidnap our heroine Rene Borden and take her across the border --- as usual Steele's stunt work and fights are the standouts of the film --- actor writer Perry Murdock plays two parts in this film as Petro the troubadour and the brawler in the cantina --- the final scene has a climatic swordfight and Steele is camaflogue in the rode and grabs onto a runaway wagon pulling himself up and capturing the villains --- another great B-Western for Bob Steele under the Supreme Picture banner, proves to be one of his most exciting performances.

Second film of the this double feature - "NEAR THE RAINBOW'S END" (10 June 1930 ) (56 mins/B&W)

Under the production staff of:
J.P. McGowan  - Director
Trem Carr  - Producer
Charles A. Post  - Screenwriter
Sally Winters  - Screenwriter
Hap Depew  - Cinematographer
T.E. Jackson  - Cinematographer
Murray Mencher  - Songwriter
Billy Moll  - Songwriter
Harry Richman  - Songwriter
Charles J. Hunt  - Editor
E.R. Hickson  - Set Designer

Our story line and plot, everyone who is a fan of Bob Steele knows this was his first sound picture --- appearing with Steele is one of my favorite character actors Lafe McKee who plays his father, both are bent on stopping the rustling by local sheepman Al Ferguson who is behind all the skullduggery on the Amity Picture Lot...the heroine is beautiful Louis Lorraine who gives a fine performance with her father silent actor Alfred Hewston --- Steele is blamed for the murder of Hewston, there is a witness but will he come forward --- saw this film in the early days of Saturday Morning Matinee B-Westerns when there were only these rare gems to entertain the American public with thise new invention...television, boy did we love it --- first special notes.actor Lafe Mckee appeared in almost 400 films, began working in Hollywood in 1913 in numerous roles mostly in B-Westerns in supporting roles with Gene Autry, Johnny Mack Brown, Gary Cooper, Hoot Gibson, Buck Jones, Ken Maynard, Tim McCoy, Bob Steele, Tom Tyler and John Wayne always as the elderly father of the heroine, a troubled businessman, ranch owner losing his homestead or having his cattle rustled, whatever the case Lafe was always in the thick of things ---- meanwhile another great B-Western for Bob Steele under the Trem Carr Production banner, proves to be one of his most exciting performances.

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other western double features --- Ask Amazon. Com to carry the volumes as they are not available on Amazon as of yet --- you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow Western Classics --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 109 min on VHS/DVD ~ Poverty Row Pictures ~ (1/30/2007)
